steps: Weighed raw materials (PbO, K2CO3, Nb2O5, Ta2O5) according to stoichiometric ratio.
Ball-milled raw materials with zirconia balls in nylon jars for 12 h.
Introduced additional 2 wt% of PbO for compensating volatilization during sintering.
Dried the powders at 120 °C.
Calcined the powders at 900 °C for 4 h.
Re-milled the calcined powders for another 6 h.
Mixed the dried powders with polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) binder.
Sieved the mixture through a screen mesh.
Pressed the particles into pellets with a diameter of 12 mm and thickness around 1.2 mm under uniaxial pressure of 15 MPa.
Fired the green pellets at 500 °C for 2 h for binder burn-out.
Sintered all specimens at 1190–1250 °C for 1 h (optimal sintering temperature determined to be 1230 °C).
Controlled cooling process at 3 °C/min till 600 °C to prevent cracking.
Performed natural cooling without quenching below 600 °C.
Coated sintered pellets with silver paste on both surfaces.
Dried coated pellets at 120 °C for 30 min to solidify electrodes.
Polarized samples in silicon oil at 150 °C with a DC electric field up to 4 kV/mm for 30 min using a high-voltage polarization system.
For annealing test, polarized samples were heated from room temperature to different annealing temperatures at 3 °C/min and held for 0.5 h, then naturally cooled down to room temperature.
For heat-treated samples, they were heated to 350 °C at 3 °C/min and held for 2 h, then naturally cooled down to room temperature before the annealing process.

steps: All raw materials were dried in an oven at approximately 120°C for 5 hours.
The weighed raw materials were mixed by ball milling for 12 hours with ethanol as a medium.
The dried raw materials were calcined at 850°C for 2 hours to obtain the object composition of NBBT100x ceramics.
The calcined powder was secondly ball milled for another 12 hours to reduce the particle size.
After dried in an oven, the calcined powder was granulated by passing through 80 mesh sieve.
Polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) aqueous solution (5 wt. %) was added as a binder (approximately 10 wt.% of the powder mass).
Before sintering, the green bodies were heated to 800°C for 2 hours to remove the binder.
NBBT100x green bodies were sintered at 1140°C-1180°C for 2 hours.
The polished ceramic disks were heated to 1100°C for 1 hour and then removed directly from the furnace to air for a rapid cooling (quenched ceramics, QS).
Ceramics normally cooled in furnace are labeled as NS.
Additional Sr or Bi was added before the calcination process for Sr- and Bi-modified NBBT6 ceramics.

steps: Raw materials (CaCO3, Bi2O3, Nb2O5, and Tm2O3) were weighed according to the stoichiometric ratio.
Raw materials were mixed by ball-milling with ZrO2 balls in ethanol for 12 hours.
The mixtures were dried.
The dried mixtures were calcined at 850 °C for 2 hours.
An additional 24-hour ball-milling was performed under the same conditions.
The synthesized CBN-100xTm powders were ground and granulated with a polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) binder.
The granulated powders were pressed into discs measuring 12 mm in diameter and 1 mm in thickness under a pressure of 150 MPa.
PVA was removed by heating at 650 °C.

Green samples were sintered in a muffle furnace: CaBi2Nb2O9 ceramics were sintered at 1150 °C for 3 hours, and thulium-substituted CBN ceramics were sintered at temperatures ranging from 1100 to 1140 °C for 3 hours (for non-textured samples).

For textured ceramics, CBN-100xTm powders were placed into a graphite die (10 mm inner diameter) and heated to 990 °C for 3 minutes at a heating rate of 100 °C/min under a constant load of 60 MPa, forming a fully densified block.
This block was then deformed in another graphite die (20 mm inner diameter) at 1130 °C for 5 minutes under a constant load of 40 MPa, with a heating rate of 100 °C/min.
After sintering, the samples were annealed in a muffle furnace at 1000 °C for 4 hours in air to remove any infiltrated carbon.

Prior to electrical measurements, the test surfaces of the samples were plated with heat-resistant electrodes (silver electrodes sintered at 570 °C for 30 minutes, or platinum electrodes sintered at 950 °C for 30 minutes).
Samples were poled under a DC electric field of 12–15 kV/mm at 180 °C for 15 minutes (before piezoelectric constant d33 measurement).

steps: PZT ceramic discs (20 mm diameter, 2 ± 0.04 mm thickness) were sourced.
Both sides of PZT discs were coated with silver using screen printing with a proprietary silver paste, free of glass frit.
Screen-printed PZT discs were fired at approximately 800°C in air to achieve a final silver coating thickness of around 25 µm.
Nickel wear plates (2 mm thick) were machined from Ni-200 rods.
The surface of the Ni wear plate was ground to achieve a planarity of approximately 10 µm and a roughness of about 1 µm.
The Ni wear plate was coated with silver using a DC sputtering process to a thickness of about 6 µm.
The silver-coated Ni surface was heated in flowing hydrogen gas at 700 °C for 2 h to facilitate silver diffusion into nickel and form a solid solution.
An additional silver coating of about 3 µm thickness was applied to the Ni wear plate, bringing the overall thickness to approximately 9 µm.
For cases 1 & 2, a 1 µm thick silver coating was applied over the screen-printed silver layer on the PZT disc using DC magnetron sputtering.
For cases 3 & 4, the screen-printed silver coating on the PZT disc was removed, and a ∼ 10 µm silver was applied.
After each 3 µm layer of silver deposition, the PZT disc was heated to 800 °C to ensure adhesion of silver to the PZT disc.
The nickel wear plate and PZT disc were placed in a sample holder within a vessel.
An initial load of approximately 1 MPa was applied to the components.
The vessel was evacuated to a high vacuum of less than -E^10E^2 Pa.
The furnace was turned on, and once the desired bonding temperature (275 °C or 400 °C) was reached, a final load of 20 MPa was applied.
The components were maintained under this pressure for 1 h.
The furnace was turned off, and the vessel was allowed to cool to room temperature.
For repoling, PZT discs bonded at 400 °C were immersed in dry silicone oil maintained at 150 °C.
A DC potential of 15 kV was applied across the disc for 15 min during repoling.
After repoling, the discs were removed from the silicone oil bath and cleaned.

Heat the samples at 800 °C for 2 h in pure alumina crucibles under an open atmosphere (pre-sintering).
Heat the samples to 1150 °C for 10 h in pure alumina crucibles under an open atmosphere, followed by slowly cooling (main sintering).
Form ceramic discs (1 mm thickness, 10 mm diameter) from the obtained powder materials.
Compact the ceramic discs using uniaxial pressing under 250 MPa pressure with 2 wt% of a 5 wt% PVA aqueous solution as a binder.
Heat the samples at 600 °C for 30 min to eliminate organic additives.
Conduct sintering at 1400 °C for 4 h.
Apply silver paste (99.9%) to the discs’ surfaces.
Heat and fire the discs with silver paste at 650 °C for 1 h to form surface electrodes.
Polish the discs on emery paper (1200 grit) to create smooth surfaces.

steps: Raw powders of (Bi0.5Na0.5)TiO3, BaCO3, TiO2, and MnO2 were weighed according to the chemical formula.
The weighed powders were ball-milled with zirconia balls (1 mm diameter) and ethanol at 250 rpm for 16 h.
The mixture was dried at 80 °C.
A 5 wt% polyvinyl butyral binder was added to the dried mixture.
The mixed powder was passed through a 250 µm mesh.

About 0.5 g of the mixed powder and a SrTiO3 seed crystal (3 mm × 3 mm × 0.5 mm, with 3 mm × 3 mm faces mirror-polished and parallel to the (110) face) were pressed into a disc compact (10 mm diameter) at 200 MPa, with the SrTiO3 seed crystal located at the center.
Several compacts were heated at 700 °C for 2 h in the air to remove the binder.
The compacts were then heated at 1200 °C for 24 h in the air for sintering in a box-type electric furnace (heating and cooling rates were 150 °C/h).
Ag paste was applied to the {110}c faces of the single crystals.
The samples with Ag paste were heated to 550 °C to form Ag electrodes.

For poling, a single crystal sample was initially heated to 150 °C, a dc electric field of 30 kV/cm was applied for 15 min, followed by cooling to 50 °C with the electric field applied, and then the electric field was removed at 50 °C.

steps: Raw materials (BaCO3, CaCO3, TiO2, ZrO2) were accurately weighed according to the stoichiometric ratio.
Weighed powder and moderate ethanol were mixed and ball-milled for 12 hours.
The mixture was placed into an oven and dried at 120 °C.
The completely dried powder was calcined at 1250 °C for 5 h.
The calcined powder was ball-milled again for 12 hours.
The ball-milled powder was pressed into a desired size and shape by a cold isostatic press machine at 30 MPa for 15 minutes.
The sample was kept at a sintering temperature of 1400–1500 °C for 4 hours to obtain a dense ceramic plate.
The ceramic sample was sanded and polished to obtain a smooth surface with a thickness of about 0.6 mm.
The ceramic plate was coated with silver paste on both sides.
The ceramic plate with silver paste was calcined at 600 °C for 30 minutes to fix the silver paste on the surfaces.
The ceramic plate placed in silicone was polarized by a Direct-Current (DC) bias of 2–3 kV/mm for 30 min under room temperature.

Mix alcohol and the oxide powders in a 1:1 ratio by wet-milling for 24 h.

Coat the polished samples with silver electrodes on both sides.
Pole the samples at 130 °C for 15 min under an electric field of 30 kV/cm.

steps: Prepare a dipeptide solution in methanol (1 mg mL-1).
Drop 10 μL of the freshly prepared dipeptide solution onto the surface of a silicon substrate.
Remove the solvent using one of three methods: (1) spontaneous evaporation, (2) forced drying with warm air (45°C), or (3) spin-coating at 3000 rpm.
For saturation experiments, place a silicon substrate with a deposited dipeptide film in a Petri dish containing an organic solvent to create saturated vapor (P/P0=1).
Seal the Petri dish and keep it at room temperature for 10 minutes to 24 hours.
After saturation, dry the film with warm air (45°C).
Perform all experiments three times to ensure reproducibility and consistency of crystal growth.

steps: Weigh precise amounts of Sc2O3, TiO2, ZnO, Bi2O3, and Pb3O4 according to the stoichiometric ratio with an excess of 1 mol% for both Bi2O3 and Pb3O4.
Subject the resulting powders to ball milling in alcohol for 12 h.
Dry the milled powders.
Calcine the powders at 750 °C for 4 h to obtain pure BZT-BS-PT ceramic powders.
Perform two rounds of milling and drying.
Carry out a granulation process by adding 5 wt% PVA to the powder mixture.
Press the ceramic green body under a uniaxial pressure of 200 MPa.
Heat treat the pressed body at 600 °C for 4 h to remove any remaining adhesive material.
Employ a buried firing process by subjecting the ceramic body to a temperature of 1000 °C for 3 h to achieve fully densified BZT-BS-PT ceramics.
Etch the cross-section of the ceramic in a mixed solution of hydrofluoric acid and hydrochloric acid.
Sputter a gold electrode on the ceramic surface with a high vacuum sputtering coater.
Polarize the ceramics in silicone oil with a direct-current field of 4 kV/mm and a temperature of 180 °C for 5 min.

steps: BCZT powder was synthesized by solid phase reaction method.
Raw materials (BaCO3, CaCO3, TiO2, ZrO2) were mixed with alcohol and ball milled for 24 hours.
The calcined powder was obtained by heating at 1300 ℃ for 3 hours.
BCZT powders for vat photopolymerization were produced by a second stage of ball milling using a range of time periods (1 h, 2 h, 4 h, 12 h).
The photosensitive resin was composed of polyurethane acrylate, 1,6-hexanediol diacrylate (HDDA), ethoxylated (5) pentaerythritol tetra acrylate (PPTTA).
Bis(2,4,6-trimethylbenzoyl)phenylphosphine oxide (Omnirad 380) was selected as the photo-initiator.
Solsperse 41000 was used as the dispersant.

The BCZT ceramic slurry was prepared by mixing the ceramic powder with light-sensitive oligomers, a diluent, photo-initiator and dispersant (0.5 wt% of the ceramic powder) using a vacuum mixer for 300 s at 2500 rpm.
The ceramic slurry was then poured into the VPP printer to produce the ceramic green body; the layer thickness was set to 30 μm.
Debinding of the resulting ceramic green body was completed in a tube furnace at 425 ℃ for 4 h, with varying temperature ramp rates of 0.1 ℃ min⁻¹, 0.2 ℃ min⁻¹ and 0.3 ℃ min⁻¹.
During the sintering process, the sample was kept at 550 ℃ for 2 h to remove any residual carbon.
The BCZT ceramic scaffold structure was obtained by heating at 3 ℃ min⁻¹ to the sintering temperature (1380 ℃, 1400 ℃, 1420 ℃, 1440 ℃) and furnace cooling to room temperature after holding for 3 h.
The sintered BCZT ceramics were directly polarized at 15 kV for 1 h using a corona poling technique.
A polyethylene glycol terephthalate (PET) film, covered with indium tin oxide (ITO), was glued to both sides of the BCZT scaffold with a silver glue.
The resulting piezoelectric sensor was obtained after curing for 12 h at room temperature.

steps: 0.1 M concentration of LNO precursor solution is prepared by dissolving equimolar quantity of Lanthanum (III) nitrate and Nickel (II) nitrate salts incorporated into glacial acetic acid and 0.01 M concentration of ethylene glycol is added and stirred for 1 hr.

0.3 M concentration of TiO precursor solution is prepared by dissolving Ti-n butoxide in glacial acetic acid and stirred for 1 hr, then 0.01 M concentration of ethylene glycol is added and stirred for 1 hr.

0.1 M concentration of PZT precursor solution is prepared by dissolving Lead (II) acetate salt in glacial acetic acid and stoichiometric concentration of Zirconium (IV) n-butoxide and Titanium (IV) n-butoxide is separately added with the lead precursor and stirred.
Appropriate amount of distilled water and ethylene glycol are added to the PZT precursor solution and stirred for 30 mins.
10 wt% of polyvinyl pyrrolidone is added to the PZT precursor solution and stirred for another 1 hr.
The PZT precursor solution is filtered using Whatman filter paper prior to deposition.
Buffer interface layers (TiO, LNO, LNO/TiO) are prepared by spin coating at 4000 rpm for 30 s.
Buffer layers are subsequently annealed at 650 °C for 30 mins.
PZT film is deposited by spin coating at 4000 rpm for 30 s.
PZT film undergoes a two-step annealing process: 400 °C for 2 mins and 650 °C for 2 mins.
All films undergo 12 cycles to achieve a desired thickness of ~1000 nm.
All films are subsequently annealed at 650 °C for 30 mins in an open-air atmosphere furnace.
Pt top electrode (thickness 100 nm) is deposited by DC sputtering.

Subjecting the stacked samples to a 5 MPa pressure applied longitudinally using an isostatic press.
Statically curing for 48 hours.
Finishing PSAs with dimensions of 6 × 6 × 6.7 mm³.
Connecting wires to PSAs.

steps: Stoichiometric raw materials (K2CO3, Na2CO3, Nb2O5, Sb2O3, Bi2O3, Fe2O3, ZrO2) were weighed.
Ball-milled the weighed raw materials in alcohol for 24 hours to reduce particle size.
Dried the mixed powder in a hot air oven at around 100°C for 24 hours to remove residual alcohol.
Sieved the dried powder to ensure uniform particle size.
Calcined the powder at 900°C for 6 hours.
Pressed the fine powder into pellets using uniaxial pressing with a pressure of about 100–200 MPa to form dense pellets.
Sintered the pellets at 1120–1140°C for 3 hours to synthesize KNNS-BF-xBNZ ceramic.
For composite films, KNNS-BF-xBNZ ceramic powder (specifically x=0.03 mol% for KNNS-BF-3BNZ) was dispersed in ethyl alcohol (99.8 %) using sonication for 3 hours to break up agglomerates.
The dispersed powder was mixed with PDMS in various proportions (0 to 30 wt%).
Combined the mixture with a curing agent (PDMS to curing agent ratio of 10:1).
Loaded the mixture into a syringe to pour a thin layer into a prepared mold.
Placed the mold at room temperature for 48 hours.
Cut the dried KNNS-BF-xBNZ/PDMS film into sheets of 3x3 cm with a thickness of 3 mm.
To prepare the PENG device, the KNNS-BF-3BNZ/PDMS composite film was sandwiched between aluminum foil sheets on both the top and bottom surfaces to serve as electrodes.

steps: Bi3Ti(1.5-x)Nb x W0.5O9 (x = 0.00, 0.01, 0.02, 0.04, 0.06, BTW-xNb) ceramics were prepared.

The BTW-xNb ceramic samples were prepared by ball milling and crushing with zirconia balls and anhydrous ethanol as the media, with a mass ratio of the raw material, ball mill sub and anhydrous ethanol of 1:2:1.5, and a ball milling time of 24 h.

steps: Mix bismuth(III) nitrate pentahydrate, sodium acetate, potassium acetate, titanium(IV) butoxide, and manganese(II) acetate in their respective stoichiometric ratios.
Use propan-2-ol and acetic acid as solvents, and pentane-2,4-dione as the polymerizing agent.
Stir the mixture at room temperature at 700 rpm with formamide.
Allow the final 0.3 M solution to polymerize for seven days.
Deposit 6 layers of BNKT-20-3M solution on commercial Pt/Ti/SiO2/Si substrate via spin-coating.
For each layer, spin at 500 rpm for 10 s and then at 4000 rpm for 30 s.
Apply a series of heat treatments after spin-coating: evaporation at 200 °C, pyrolysis at 500 °C, and annealing at 750 °C, each for 5 min.
Repeat the above-described sequence 6 times, resulting in a thin-film sample approximately 220 nm thick.
Some thin-film samples were further heat-treated in a nitrogen (N2) atmosphere at 1 atm, 750 °C for 30 min after the cooling procedure for defect passivation.
Deposit circular Pt top electrodes with an area of 0.283 mm² on the thin-film sample by RF magnetron sputtering in argon plasma.

steps: Synthesized 0.15PSN-0.57PMN-0.28PT matrix powder (average 300 nm particle size) using traditional solid state reaction method.
Produced pure perovskite matrix powder by sintering the mixed raw materials at 750 °C for 2 h.
Synthesized plate-like BT templates with [001] orientation by the topochemical transformation technique.
Sliced, stacked, and compressed embryo strips for 30 min at 70 °C with 10 MPa of pressure.
Discharged organic matters by sintering at 550 °C for 2 h.
Subjected samples to isostatic pressing at a pressure of 200 MPa for 1 min.
Sintered the sample in an air atmosphere at 1200–1270 °C for 0–11 h.

article_metadata.title: Microstructure and electric properties in PSN-PMN-PT textured ceramics by template grain growth technology

steps: 0.5Pb(Ni1/3Nb2/3)O3-0.16PbZrO3-0.34PbTiO3 matrix powders were synthesized by conventional solid-state reaction with the raw materials PbO, NiO, Nb2O5, ZrO2, and TiO2.
The mixture of raw materials was ball-milled using zirconia balls (Φ = 1 mm, 3 mm, 5 mm, and 10 mm) for 24 h and dried at 90°C.
The milled PNN-PZT powders were calcined at 850°C for 4 h (heating rate: 5°C/min).
0.2 wt% of Li2CO3 was added to the calcined 0.5Pb(Ni1/3Nb2/3)O3-0.16PbZrO3-0.34PbTiO3 powder as a sintering aid.
The mixture was subsequently ball-milled for 48 h with zirconia balls (Φ = 1 mm, 3 mm, 5 mm, and 10 mm) and dried at 90°C.

Ethyl alcohol, toluene, dibutyl phthalate, polyvinyl butyral, and dispersant were mixed with PNNZT powders at an optimized ratio and ball-milled for 24 h with zirconia balls (Φ = 3 mm, 5 mm, 10 mm, and 15 mm).
After ball milling, the PNNZT slurry was separated from the zirconia balls using a mesh fabric, and any remaining air bubbles were removed using a vacuum chamber for 15 min.
An aging process followed for 2 h at 15 rpm to stabilize the slurry.
BT-template-free thick sheets were prepared via tape casting at a casting speed of 1 m/min with a blade gap of 85 μm.

Ethyl alcohol, toluene, dibutyl phthalate, polyvinyl butyral, and dispersant were mixed with PNNZT powders at an optimized ratio and ball-milled for 24 h with zirconia balls (Φ = 3 mm, 5 mm, 10 mm, and 15 mm).
After ball milling, the PNNZT slurry was separated from the zirconia balls using a mesh fabric.
BT templates were dispersed in a small amount of ethanol using a sonicator for 5 min and then added to the separated PNNZT slurry.
Any remaining air bubbles in the slurry were removed using a vacuum chamber for 15 min.
The slurry was then aged for 2 h at 15 rpm to stabilize it.
BT-included thin sheets were prepared via tape casting at a casting speed of 1 m/min with a blade gap of 8 μm.
The obtained PNNZT and PNNZT-BT sheets were alternately laminated, one by one, using a lamination machine under 10 MPa of pressure and at a temperature of 60°C.
The laminated sheets were then subjected to a warm isostatic pressing (WIP) process by applying 25 MPa of pressure at 65°C for 20 min.
After the WIP process, the PNNZT/PNNZT-BT laminates were cut into 10 mm × 10 mm pieces using a blade cutter.
To burn out the organic components, the cut pieces were fired at 300°C and 600°C for 5 h at each temperature, with a heating rate of 1°C/min.
The fired PNNZT/PNNZT-BT laminates were pressed using a cold isostatic press (CIP) machine for 1 min under 200 MPa at room temperature.
The CIP-treated specimens were then sintered at various temperatures ranging from 900°C to 1025°C, in 25°C intervals, for 15 h under an O2 atmosphere (flow rate: 1 L/min, heating rate: 1°C/min).
After sintering, Ag paste was applied to both sides of the sintered body and fired at 700°C for 10 min.
Poling was conducted at 3.5 kV/mm for 20 min at room temperature in silicone oil.

steps: Pure Mg samples (30 mm × 15 mm × 2 mm) were mechanically ground with SiC paper up to 1000 grit.
Samples were ultrasonically cleaned in ethyl alcohol.
Samples were dried in cold air.
During the PEO process, Mg plates were used as the anode, and a stainless steel chamber was used as the cathode and reactor.
A pulse reverse power provided a constant current of 2 A/dm² for 660 s under a frequency of 500 Hz and a duty cycle of 15 %.
The electrolyte was prepared based on silicate salt (20 g/L Na2SiO3 + 4 g/L KF + 2 g/L NaOH).
BaTiO3 powder (globular, 100–200 nm) was added to the electrolyte at concentrations of 2 g/L (for PEO-BTO2) and 5 g/L (for PEO-BTO5).
The solution was cooled down using a water-cooling system at 30 ± 5 °C during the coating process.
After PEO treatment, the samples were rinsed in distilled water.
Samples were dried in warm air.

Re-mill the calcined powder for 24 h at 250 rpm using a planetary ball mill with ethanol and yttrium stabilized zirconia balls.
Add water (5 % weight fraction) dropwise to the powder.
Apply a force of 45 kN (400 MPa) over 40 min, with a gradual temperature increase of 5 °C/min, reaching 200 °C (cold sintering step) using an SPS machine in vacuum.

steps: Weighed raw materials (Bi2O3, Na2CO3, K2CO3, TiO2, Ta2O5, Sb2O5, ZrO2, HfO2) and ethanol are poured into a jar and ball milled for 24 h with ZrO2 balls.
The dried powders are calcined at 850 °C for 6 h.
The calcined powders are mixed according to the proportion of the corresponding components, and ethanol is poured into a jar and ball milled for 24 h with ZrO2 balls.
The dried mixed powders are granulated into a floc with 8 wt% polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) as a binder.
The granulated floc is pressed into disks (1 mm in thickness and 10 mm in diameter) under a pressure of 10 MPa.
PVA is removed from the disks.
The disks are buried in the calcined powders and sintered at 1150 °C for 3 h in an air atmosphere. The heating rate from RT to 1000 °C is 5 °C/min, and 3 °C/min beyond 1000 °C.

steps: Starting materials (BaCO3, SrCO3, TiO2, and ZrO2) were mixed in stoichiometric ratios.
Mixture was subjected to ball milling in ethanol at 400 rpm for 12 h.
The mixture underwent drying.
The dried mixture was fired at 1200 °C for 2 h (calcination).
After calcination, the material was thoroughly blended with 5 wt% polyvinyl alcohol (PVA).
The blended material was compacted into discs measuring 15 mm in across and 1 mm in thickness by applying a pressure of 10 MPa.
The molded ceramics were placed in a muffle furnace, ramped to 650 °C at a rate of 5 °C/min, and held for 2 h to eliminate PVA.
Followed by heating to 1400 °C at 5 °C/min and sintering in the air for 3 h.
For electrical characterization, the ceramic surfaces were first uniformly coated with silver paste on both sides using a screen.
The coated ceramics were then heated at 600 °C for 0.5 h to cure the paste.
Ultimately, the ceramics were immersed in a silicone oil bath at 40 °C.
The ceramics were subjected to polarization with a direct-current (DC) field of 30 kV/cm for 20 min.

steps: Carbonates (BaCO3) were dried in an oven at 120 °C for more than 2 h.

After drying, the powder mixture was calcined twice at 800 °C for 2 h.
The calcined powders were milled for 12 h.
The milled powders were pressed into disks with 12.7 mm in diameter using polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) as a binder.
The green compacts were first fired at 600 °C to remove the PVA binder.
The compacts were then sintered in ambient atmosphere at a temperature in the range of 1000 °C–1020 °C for 2 h.
The sintered disks were subjected to mechanical polishing to obtain a thickness of ~0.35 mm.
Gold electrodes were sputtered onto ceramic surfaces for electrical measurements.

steps: Weigh sodium acetate, strontium acetate, bismuth acetate, and barium acetate according to the stoichiometric ratio.
Add weighed precursors to solvents.
Use 12 mol% excess sodium acetate and 2 mol% excess bismuth acetate to compensate for possible evaporation.
Stir the mixture at 80°C for one hour to obtain the precursor solution of BNT-ST-100xBT.
Adjust solvent content to achieve a solution concentration of 0.4 mol/L.
Deposit BNT-ST-100xBT solution on pretreated Pt/TiO2/SiO2/Si substrates by spin coating.
Drop the solution onto the substrate.
Rotate the substrate at 1500 r/min for 10 s.
Rotate the substrate at 3000 r/min for 40 s to ensure uniform and complete coverage.
Place the deposited film in a rapid thermal treatment (RTP) furnace for heat treatment.
Perform pyrolysis at 150°C for 3 min to evaporate the solvent.
Perform pyrolysis at 410°C for 10 min to remove organic components.
Perform annealing at 725°C for 3 min for crystallization.
Repeat the deposition and heating procedures 6 times to achieve the designed thickness.
Prepare Au electrodes with a diameter of 0.3 mm onto the surface of thin films by DC sputtering.

steps: Precisely weigh raw materials based on stoichiometric ratio.

steps: Precursors dried for a minimum of 12 hours in a 120 °C drying oven.
Ball milling conducted in 100 % ethanol with a 250 mL ZrO2 milling jar and 5 mm ZrO2 media for 3 h at 125 rpm.
Resulting slurry dried using a rotary evaporator.
Ground with an agate mortar and pestle.
Sieved with a 250 µm mesh stainless steel sieve.
Three individual calcination pellets (3.0 g, 25 mm diameter) uniaxially pressed under 5 MPa in a stainless-steel die.
Calcination took place in a muffle furnace at 801.5 °C for 4 hours with a heating rate of 3 °C/min and a cooling rate of approximately 4 °C/min.
Following calcination, pellets milled in 100 % ethanol with a 250 mL ZrO2 milling jar and 5 mm ZrO2 media for 30 minutes at 125 rpm.
Resulting slurry dried using a rotary evaporator.
Ground with an agate mortar and pestle.
Sieved with a 150 µm mesh stainless steel sieve.
Approximately 24 sintering pellets (0.30 g, 10 mm diameter) uniaxially pressed under 30 MPa in a stainless-steel die.
Pellets then isostatically pressed under 200 MPa with a dwell time of one minute.
Pellets sintered in batches of 3 in a partially closed alumina crucible with sacrificial powder.
Sintering took place in a muffle furnace at 1103.5 °C for 2 hours with a heating rate of 5 °C/min and a cooling rate of approximately 4 °C/min.
Sintered pellets prepared to a 1 µm surface finish (silicon carbide paper to 5 µm, polycrystalline diamond paste to 1 µm).
Some pellets thermally etched (1037.5 °C for 7 minutes; heating rate 5 °C/min).
All SEM/EDX specimens carbon coated (approximately 20 nm thickness).

steps: Prepare nonwoven ES fiber mats of P(VDF-TrFE) 80/20 from 12 wt% methyl ether ketone (MEK) solution using electrospinning equipped with a grounded rolling collector.
Apply multi-step thermal annealing processes to achieve ECCs with thickened ferroelectric domains.
Employ corona-charging to achieve permanent remanent polarization (Pr0) for piezoelectricity.

First thermal annealing (1A) process: Hold the ES fiber mat isothermally at 140 °C for various times (10, 60, 180, 360, 720, 1440, and 2880 min) to produce ECCs via chain-sliding motions in the paraelectric phase.

Second annealing (2A) process: Carry out for ES1A-2880 min below TC with a fixed isothermal time of 1 day at temperatures of 110, 115, 125, and 130 °C to further increase the ferroelectric domain size.
For corona-poling in air: Pole the fiber mats with corona-poling in air at room temperature for 30 min, with the distance between the high-voltage probe and the fiber mat not shorter than 2 cm.
To eliminate self-polarized Pr0 in as-electrospun fiber mats: Thermally anneal samples at 140 °C for 60 min under a short-circuit condition.
For corona-poling in water: Use AC corona poling at 500 kHz with a probe-to-fiber mat distance of 0.5 cm. After corona-poling, dry the fiber mats in vacuum.

steps: BZT (BaZr0.05Ti0.95O3) powder was prepared using the mixed oxide method by calcining barium carbonate, zirconium dioxide, and titanium dioxide at 1200 °C for 2 h.
BZT powder was pressed into a disc shape of ~15 mm diameter and a thickness of ~1.5 mm with an applied pressure of ~85 MPa.
BZT discs were sintered at 1450 °C for 2 h.
BZT discs (dimension ~12 mm and thickness ~1.5 mm) were poled using an electric field of 1.5 kV/mm at 50 °C for 30 min in a silicone oil chamber.
Poled BZT ceramic was cut using a diamond saw in a parallel direction along with the polarization axis (cut and fill method).
Mixtures of Portland cement powder, water (water to cement ratio (w/c) = 0.35), epoxy resin, and hardener (volume ratio of epoxy resin and hardener = 7.5) were used as the matrix phase.
The mixture was filled into the cut areas of the BZT ceramic.
The samples were then cured in a controlled chamber at 60 °C for 5 days at 98 %RH.

steps: 1 g colemanite, 80 mg Fe2O3, 500 mg BaCO3, and 500 mg TiO2 were mixed.
The mixture was subjected to ball milling for 15 h at a rotational speed of 300 rpm.
2 mL of 13.8 M ammonia solution was added to the mixture.
The mixture was then ball-milled for an additional 3 min at the same rotational speed.
The resulting mixture was transferred onto a silicon carbide plate (3 cm × 2 cm).
The ammonia solution was evaporated by heating the plate on a hot plate set to 150 °C.
The SiC plate with the residual mixture was placed into a tubular furnace.
The furnace temperature was gradually increased to 1300 °C and maintained for 3 h under a continuous flow of NH3 gas.
Upon completion of the reaction, the NH3 gas flow was stopped at 975 °C.
The furnace was allowed to cool to room temperature.

steps: Raw materials were weighed according to BTN-100xCe nominal composition.
Raw materials were ball mixed for 24 h with anhydrous ethanol and zirconia balls medium.
After separating the balls, the mixed slurries were dried.
Mixed slurries were calcined at 800 °C for 3 h.
Calcined powders were ball milled for 24 h again.
The dried powders were granulated by polyvinyl alcohol solution (PVA, 5 wt%) as adhesive.
Granulated powders were pressed into green pellets of 13 mm diameter and about 1.0 mm thick under a pressure of 120 ± 10 MPa.
The green pellets were fired at 650 °C for 3 h to burn off the PVA.
The green pellets were sintered at 1065 °C–1105 °C for 3 h in air with 5 °C/min.
Sintered pellets were furnace-cooled to ambient temperature.
Sintered pellets were parallel polished on both sides to about 0.6 mm thick.
Polished pellets were painted with silver paste.
Painted pellets were fired for 30 min at 800 °C to form electrodes.
For piezoelectric measurements, the ceramic samples were poled at 160 °C for 20–30 min in silicone oil bath applied with an electric field of 100~150 kV/cm.

synthesis_data.method: Solid-state reaction, Uniaxial pressing, Freeze casting, 3D printing, Chemical pre-treatment, Ultrasonic defibrillation, Solution mixing, Hydrolysis, Freeze-drying, High-temperature drying
steps: Weigh raw materials (Barium carbonate, Calcium carbonate, Zirconium oxide, Titanium oxide) according to stoichiometric ratio.
Mix raw materials with ethanol and ball-mill for 24 h.
Dry the ethanol-ceramic slurry in an oven.
Grind the dried slurry into a powder for calcination.
Heat treat (calcine) at 1250 °C for 3 h with a heating ramping rate of 5 °C/min.
Grind the calcinated powders.
Sieve the calcinated powders using a mesh with a size of 63 µm to obtain BCZT powder.
For dense BCZT ceramics: Mix BCZT powders with poly(vinyl alcohol) (PVA) as a binding agent.
For dense BCZT ceramics: Uni-axially cold-compact the mixture at a pressure of 80 MPa to form the green body.
For dense BCZT ceramics: Heat the green body to 500 °C for 2 h using a ramp rate of 1 °C/min to burn out organic agents.
For dense BCZT ceramics: Sinter at 1400 °C for 10 h with a ramp rate of 5 °C/min.
For porous BCZT ceramics (freeze casting): Ball mill BCZT powders for 24 h with deionized water, poly(vinyl alcohol) (PVA), and ammonium polyacrylate to form a slurry (~20 vol% solid loading).
For porous BCZT ceramics: Pour the slurry into a cylindrical mold with polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) on the sides and high thermal conductivity metal on the bottom.
For porous BCZT ceramics: Unidirectionally freeze the slurry at -80 °C.
For porous BCZT ceramics: Remove ice by freeze drying to form a porous BCZT green body.
For porous BCZT ceramics: Sinter the green bodies at 500 °C for 2 h (ramp rate 1 °C/min) followed by 1400 °C for 10 h (ramp rate 5 °C/min).
Form sintered BCZT ceramics (dense and porous) into a dimension with a thickness of 1 mm and a diameter of 10 mm.
For microrobot shell: 3D print acrylic parts using a commercial digital light processing (DLP) 3D printer.
For microrobot assembly: Mount BCZT ceramics at the rear of the robot housing.
For microrobot assembly: Fix a steel M4 nut at the front of the housing.
For microrobot assembly: Create two small holes (0.3 mm in diameter) at the top of the central section of the robot housing.
For microrobot assembly: Join acrylic parts of the swimmer with a universal adhesive.
For microrobot assembly: Attach cellulose foam to the structure using adhesive tape.
For nanocellulose: Sieve poplar wood powder through a 60 mesh.
For nanocellulose: Soak wood powder in sodium chlorite for 1 h at 75 °C under acidic conditions (repeat five times).
For nanocellulose: Filter to neutrality (pH = 7).
For nanocellulose: Soak wood flour in 5 wt% potassium hydroxide in a water bath at 90 °C for 2 h.
For nanocellulose: Filter to neutrality (pH = 7).
For nanocellulose: Treat samples with acidified sodium chlorite twice for 1 h in a 75 °C water bath.
For nanocellulose: Treat samples once for 2 h in a 90 °C water bath with 5 wt% potassium hydroxide.
For nanocellulose: Defibrillate cellulose using a high-intensity ultrasonic apparatus (800 W, 30 min) to obtain a 0.8 wt% suspension of nanofibrillated cellulose (NFC).
For composite aerogels: Prepare 3 wt% chitosan solution with 2 mol/L glacial acetic acid as the solvent.
For composite aerogels: Prepare chitosan uniform dispersion by magnetic stirring for 8 h at room temperature.
For composite aerogels: Mix 0.8 wt% nanofibrillated cellulose suspension and chitosan uniform dispersion at a mass ratio of 1:1 and stir evenly.
For composite aerogels: Adjust 80 mL of deionized water to pH = 4 using hydrochloric acid.
For composite aerogels: Add 2.5 g of trimethoxymethylsilane dropwise to hydrolyze.
For composite aerogels: Magnetic stir at room temperature for 10 min.
For composite aerogels: Add the hydrolyzed trimethoxymethylsilane reagent to the nanofibrillated cellulose/chitosan solution and stir evenly.
For composite aerogels: Freeze-dry samples under a vacuum with a cold trap at -55 °C and a vacuum degree of 1.0 MPa for 72 h.
For composite aerogels: Place composite aerogels in an oven at 90 °C and dry at a high temperature of 850 °C for 3 h.
